#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)

model_graded_qa(partial_credit = TRUE).explanation:
I need to evaluate whether the submission meets the criterion for allowing named discrete breaks to be used as labels by default.

The criterion suggests two specific changes:

1. In the `init` function, change 
   ```
   if (scale$is_discrete()) {
     self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
   }
   ```
   to
   ```
   if (scale$is_discrete()) {
     self$breaks <- setNames(scale$get_breaks())
   }
   ```

2. In the `break_info` function, change
   ```
   else {
     breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
   }
   ```
   to
   ```
   else {
     breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))
   }
   ```

The submission does not make either of these changes. Instead, it proposes adding a conditional check in the `init` function that would set `self$labels` based on the names of `self$breaks` if certain conditions are met. 

While the submission is attempting to address the issue of using named breaks as labels, it doesn't implement the specific solution required by the criterion. The criterion specifies that the names of the breaks should be preserved during mapping operations, which the submission doesn't address.

The submission's approach might work in some cases, but it doesn't follow the specific implementation requested in the criterion.

Here's a file implementing secondary axes in ggplot2:

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

Please propose edits so that, when discrete breaks have names, they'll be used as labels by default.

        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)

#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step using tidyverse functions.

First, I need to:
1. Group the flights by `tailnum`
2. Count the total flights and the number of NA `arr_delay` values for each plane
3. Calculate the proportion of NA values
4. Filter for planes with at least 100 flights
5. Find the plane with the highest proportion of NA values

Here's the code:

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
- Groups flights by tail number
- Calculates total flights and counts NA values in arr_delay
- Computes the proportion of flights with missing arrival delay
- Filters to include only planes with at least 100 flights
- Sorts in descending order by the NA proportion
- Takes the first row (highest proportion)
- Returns just the tail number value

The result will be the tail number of the plane with the highest proportion of missing arrival delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step using tidyverse functions.

First, I need to:
1. Group the flights by `tailnum`
2. Count the total flights and the number of NA `arr_delay` values for each plane
3. Calculate the proportion of NA values
4. Filter for planes with at least 100 flights
5. Find the plane with the highest proportion of NA values

Here's the code:

```r
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
- Groups flights by tail number
- Calculates total flights and counts NA values in arr_delay
- Computes the proportion of flights with missing arrival delay
- Filters to include only planes with at least 100 flights
- Sorts in descending order by the NA proportion
- Takes the first row (highest proportion)
- Returns just the tail number value

The result will be the tail number of the plane with the highest proportion of missing arrival delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

content.text:
I'll write code to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among those that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate the number of flights and proportion of NA arr_delays for each tailnum
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_proportion = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  # Filter for tailnums with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Arrange in descending order of NA proportion
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights data by tailnum
2. For each tailnum, calculates the total number of flights and the proportion of flights with NA arr_delay values
3. Filters to keep only tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Sorts by the proportion of NAs in descending order
5. Takes the first row (the tailnum with the highest proportion of NAs)
6. Extracts just the tailnum value

This will give you the tailnum with the highest proportion of missing arrival delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 times.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step.

First, I need to filter the `flights` dataset to find the `tailnum`s that have at least 100 flights. Then, for each `tailnum`, I'll calculate the proportion of flights where `arr_delay` is NA. Finally, I'll find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion.

Here's the code:

```r
flights %>%
  # Count flights and NA arr_delays by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter for tailnums with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by proportion of NA arr_delays (highest first)
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, prop_na, total_flights)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights by `tailnum`
2. Calculates the total number of flights and the number of flights with NA `arr_delay` values
3. Computes the proportion of flights with NA `arr_delay`
4. Filters to include only those with at least 100 flights
5. Sorts in descending order by the proportion of NA values
6. Takes the first row (highest proportion)
7. Returns the `tailnum` along with its proportion of NA values and total flight count

2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The criterion specifies three main steps:

  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%

- It then filters for `tailnum`s with at least 100 flights
- It calculates the proportion using division rather than `mean(is.na(arr_delay))`

While this approach will produce the correct result (the tailnum with highest proportion of NA arr_delays), it doesn't follow the specific method required in the criterion. The criterion specifically requires filtering before summarizing, and using `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` directly.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step.

First, I need to filter the `flights` dataset to find the `tailnum`s that have at least 100 flights. Then, for each `tailnum`, I'll calculate the proportion of flights where `arr_delay` is NA. Finally, I'll find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion.

Here's the code:

```r
flights %>%
  # Count flights and NA arr_delays by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter for tailnums with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by proportion of NA arr_delays (highest first)
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, prop_na, total_flights)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights by `tailnum`
2. Calculates the total number of flights and the number of flights with NA `arr_delay` values
3. Computes the proportion of flights with NA `arr_delay`
4. Filters to include only those with at least 100 flights
5. Sorts in descending order by the proportion of NA values
6. Takes the first row (highest proportion)
7. Returns the `tailnum` along with its proportion of NA values and total flight count

Here's the code:

```r

  group_by(tailnum) %>%

```

This code:
1. Groups the flights by `tailnum`
2. Calculates the total number of flights and the number of flights with NA `arr_delay` values
3. Computes the proportion of flights with NA `arr_delay`

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

```

 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.

! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

content.text:
# Error in `mutate()` with `by` Argument

The error you're encountering is because you're trying to use the `by` argument directly inside `mutate()`, but the `by` parameter doesn't work that way in `mutate()`.

## What's happening:

The error message `by must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984` indicates that:
- You're trying to pass vectors for `id` and `date` directly to `by`
- These vectors are being concatenated, doubling the expected size

## How to fix it:

Use one of these approaches instead:

### Option 1: Use `group_by()` before `mutate()`
```r
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(your_calculations) %>%
  ungroup()
```

### Option 2: Use `by = c("id", "date")` syntax
If you're using dplyr 1.1.0 or newer, use quoted column names:

```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    your_calculations,
    .by = c("id", "date")
  )
```

Note the `.by` syntax (with the dot) and that column names must be in quotes.

### Option 3: For newer versions only
With recent dplyr, the syntax is:

```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    your_calculations,
    by = c(id, date)
  )
```

Without seeing your exact code, I recommend trying Option 1 first as it's the most universally compatible.

# Understanding and Fixing the `.by` Error in `mutate()`

## The Error Explained

This error occurs because you're trying to use the `.by` parameter directly inside the `mutate()` function's arguments list, which is incorrect syntax.

```r
# Incorrect usage that causes your error
data %>% 
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    by = c(id, date)  # This syntax is wrong
  )
```

The error message "by must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984" suggests that R is interpreting your `by = c(id, date)` as trying to create a new column called "by" rather than using it as the grouping parameter.

## How to Fix It

There are two correct ways to use `.by`:

### Option 1: Use `.by` as a parameter to `mutate()`

```r
data %>% 
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    .by = c(id, date)  # Note the dot before "by"
  )
```

### Option 2: Pass a named list to `.by`

```r
data %>% 
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    .by = c("id", "date")  # Using strings for column names
  )
```

### Alternative: Use `group_by()` and `ungroup()`

If you continue having issues with `.by`, you can use the traditional grouping approach:

```r
data %>% 
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_column = some_calculation()) %>%
  ungroup()
```

The main issue was likely missing the dot prefix in `.by` or trying to reference the column names directly instead of as strings.

I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
# Fixing `.by` Error in `mutate()`

The error you're encountering occurs because you're incorrectly specifying the `by` parameter inside `mutate()`. 

## The Problem

The error message indicates that:
- Your `by` argument is creating a vector with 5,818,984 elements
- But it should have either 2,909,492 elements (the number of rows in your dataframe) or 1 element

## The Solution

When using `by` in `mutate()`, you should specify it at the same level as the mutation, not inside the mutation. Here's the correct syntax:

```r
# INCORRECT (what you're likely doing)
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    by = c(id, date)  # This is wrong
  )

# CORRECT
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_column = some_calculation(),
    .by = c(id, date)  # Note the dot prefix and placement
  )
```

## Alternative Approaches

If you're using an older version of dplyr (< 1.1.0), use `group_by()` and `ungroup()`:

```r
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_column = some_calculation()) %>%
  ungroup()
```

## Important Notes

1. In newer dplyr versions, the parameter has a dot prefix (`.by`) within mutate
2. Ensure the variables you're grouping by (id, date) actually exist in your dataframe
3. If you're using bare column names (without quotes), make sure to load dplyr

samples.input:
Add a `name` argument after `dataset` that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling env.

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.
samples.target:
```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

samples.input: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?
samples.target: Either set `geom_jitter(height = 0)` or `geom_point(position = position_jitter(height = 0))`.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
# Jittering Points in ggplot2 on X-Axis Only

To jitter points only on the x-axis in ggplot2 while keeping y values unchanged, you can use `geom_jitter()` with specific parameters or `position_jitter()`.

## Option 1: Using geom_jitter() with width parameter

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_var, y = y_var)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

The parameters:
- `width = 0.2`: Controls the amount of horizontal jittering (adjust as needed)
- `height = 0`: Prevents any vertical jittering

## Option 2: Using position_jitter() explicitly

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_var, y = y_var)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

## Full Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(123)
df <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30, 5, 1)
)

# Plot with x-axis jittering only
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Points jittered only on x-axis")
```

This will create a plot where points are spread horizontally around their x position but maintain their exact y values.

# Jittering Points in ggplot2 on X-Axis Only

To jitter points only on the x-axis in ggplot2 while keeping y values unchanged, you can use `geom_jitter()` with specific parameters or `position_jitter()`.

## Option 1: Using geom_jitter() with width parameter

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_var, y = y_var)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

The parameters:
- `width = 0.2`: Controls the amount of horizontal jittering (adjust as needed)
- `height = 0`: Prevents any vertical jittering

## Option 2: Using position_jitter() explicitly

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_var, y = y_var)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

## Full Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(123)
df <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30, 5, 1)
)

# Plot with x-axis jittering only
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Points jittered only on x-axis")
```

This will create a plot where points are spread horizontally around their x position but maintain their exact y values.

content.text:
# Jittering Points Only on the X-Axis in ggplot2

To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2 while leaving the y values unchanged, you can use the `position_jitter()` function with specific parameters.

## Basic Approach

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

The key is setting:
- `width` - Controls the amount of horizontal jittering (set to your desired amount)
- `height = 0` - Ensures no vertical jittering occurs

## Complete Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
df <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 1)
)

# Plot with x-axis jittering only
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0), 
             size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Points Jittered Only on X-Axis")
```

## Alternative Form

You can also use the shorthand `geom_jitter()` with the same parameters:

```r
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, size = 3, alpha = 0.7)
```

Both approaches will produce the same result - points that are jittered horizontally while maintaining their exact vertical positions.

content.text:
# Jittering Points Only on the X-Axis in ggplot2

To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2 while leaving the y values unchanged, you can use the `position_jitter()` function with specific parameters.

## Basic Approach

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

The key is setting:
- `width` - Controls the amount of horizontal jittering (set to your desired amount)
- `height = 0` - Ensures no vertical jittering occurs

## Complete Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
df <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30, mean = 5, sd = 1)
)

# Plot with x-axis jittering only
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0), 
             size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Points Jittered Only on X-Axis")
```

## Alternative Form

You can also use the shorthand `geom_jitter()` with the same parameters:

```r
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, size = 3, alpha = 0.7)
```

Both approaches will produce the same result - points that are jittered horizontally while maintaining their exact vertical positions.

# Jittering Points in ggplot2 Only Along the X-axis

To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2, you can use the `position_jitter()` function with the `width` parameter set to your desired amount of jittering and the `height` parameter set to 0.

Here's how to do it:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

In this example:
- `width = 0.2` controls the amount of horizontal jittering (adjust this value to your needs)
- `height = 0` ensures there is no vertical jittering

## Alternative syntax

You can also use the shorthand `position = "jitter"` with the `width` and `height` parameters:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

This approach is particularly useful when you have categorical variables on the x-axis and want to avoid overplotting without distorting the actual y-values of your data points.

content.text:
# Jittering Points in ggplot2 Only Along the X-axis

To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2, you can use the `position_jitter()` function with the `width` parameter set to your desired amount of jittering and the `height` parameter set to 0.

Here's how to do it:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

In this example:
- `width = 0.2` controls the amount of horizontal jittering (adjust this value to your needs)
- `height = 0` ensures there is no vertical jittering

## Alternative syntax

You can also use the shorthand `position = "jitter"` with the `width` and `height` parameters:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

This approach is particularly useful when you have categorical variables on the x-axis and want to avoid overplotting without distorting the actual y-values of your data points.

samples.input:
I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
samples.target: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.

content.text:
The issue is that when using non-standard evaluation (NSE) with `deparse(substitute(...))`, it evaluates to the full representation of the object rather than just the symbol name when you pass a variable that's already been evaluated.

Here's how to fix your function so the default name will be the symbol name:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # If name is NULL, try to get the variable name used for dataset
    if (is.null(name)) {
      name <- as.character(substitute(dataset))
    }
    
    # Rest of your function...
    # ...
}
```

This way:

1. When `dataset` is passed as a symbol (variable name), `substitute(dataset)` will return that symbol
2. `as.character()` converts the symbol to a character string
3. If the user explicitly provides a name parameter, it will use that instead

This approach should correctly capture "simple_addition" as the name in your example. The key difference is checking for NULL first and using `as.character()` instead of `deparse()`, which can produce overly verbose results for complex objects.

model_graded_qa(partial_credit = TRUE).explanation:
I need to evaluate whether the submission addresses the issue with the `name` parameter being evaluated lazily in the function.

The criterion specifically mentions that:
1. The `name` default is evaluated lazily
2. Something causes `dataset` to be evaluated before `name`
3. The solution should force early evaluation of `name` using something like `force(name)`

Looking at the submission, it changes the approach by:
1. Making `name` default to `NULL` instead of using `deparse(substitute(dataset))`
2. Then checking if `name` is `NULL` inside the function body and only then trying to get the variable name

While this approach does change how the name is determined, it doesn't actually address the lazy evaluation problem identified in the criterion. The submission doesn't use `force(name)` or any equivalent method to ensure that `name` is evaluated early in the function. 

The issue in the original code is that by the time `name` is evaluated (lazily), `dataset` has already been evaluated to its full value, causing `deparse(substitute(dataset))` to represent the entire data structure rather than just the variable name.

The submission changes the design of the function but doesn't directly address the lazy evaluation issue mentioned in the criterion.

GRADE: I

2. Something causes `dataset` to be evaluated before `name`
3. The solution should force early evaluation of `name`, e.g., using `force(name)`

Looking at the submission, the author provides two solutions:

1. Using rlang's quosure system to capture the expression before evaluation
2. Using match.call() to get the calling argument's name

Neither solution explicitly uses `force(name)` as suggested in the criterion. Instead, both solutions change the default value of `name` to `NULL` and then set it conditionally inside the function body.

The correct approach according to the criterion would be to keep the original default:
```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)  # Force immediate evaluation of name
  # Rest of function...
}
```

Since the submission doesn't follow this specific approach and misdiagnoses the root cause of the problem (lazy evaluation), it doesn't meet the criterion.

[Submission]: # Fixing the Default Name Issue

The problem is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` is being evaluated inside the function, after the argument `dataset` has already been evaluated to its value. Therefore, it's giving you the deparsed representation of the tibble itself, not the variable name.

## Solution

You need to capture the argument name *before* it gets evaluated. Here are two approaches:

### Option 1: Using rlang's quosure system

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Capture the expression used for 'dataset'
  dataset_expr <- rlang::enquo(dataset)
  
  # Use the expression as default name if name is NULL
  if (is.null(name)) {
    # Try to get a clean name from the expression
    name <- rlang::quo_name(dataset_expr)
    # If it's still too complex, use a generic name
    if (nchar(name) > 100) {
      name <- "dataset"
    }
  }
  
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

### Option 2: Simpler approach with default arguments

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # If name is NULL, try to get the calling argument's name
  if (is.null(name)) {
    call <- match.call()
    if (!is.null(call$dataset)) {
      name <- deparse(call$dataset)
      # Ensure name isn't too complex
      if (nchar(name) > 100) {
        name <- "dataset"
      }
    } else {
      name <- "dataset"
    }
  }
  
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

Both of these approaches will correctly capture the variable name used for the `dataset` argument when the function is called, giving you "simple_addition" in your example.

The second approach is simpler but might not handle all edge cases as robustly as the rlang approach.

content.text:
# Fixing the `name` Parameter Default in `task_create`

The issue is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` is evaluating in the context of the function call, not the calling environment. Since you're passing the actual dataset object, that's what gets substituted and deparsed (resulting in the full structure output).

## Solution

Replace your current approach with:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Get the name from the caller's environment if not provided
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

This approach:

1. Makes `name` parameter explicitly optional with `NULL` default
2. Uses `deparse(substitute(dataset))` only when name isn't provided
3. Captures the variable name as it appears in the caller's code

## Alternative (More Robust)

For a more robust solution that handles complex expressions:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Get the name from caller if not provided
  if (is.null(name)) {
    call <- sys.call()
    mc <- match.call()
    dataset_expr <- mc$dataset
    name <- deparse(dataset_expr)
  }
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

This uses `match.call()` to get the actual expression used for the dataset parameter, which works even with more complex expressions.

The correct approach according to the criterion would be to keep the original default but add `force(name)` at the beginning of the function body to ensure `name` is evaluated before anything else happens with `dataset`.

content.text:
# Fixing the `name` Parameter Default in `task_create`

The issue is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` is evaluating in the context of the function call, not the calling environment. Since you're passing the actual dataset object, that's what gets substituted and deparsed (resulting in the full structure output).

## Solution

Replace your current approach with:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Get the name from the caller's environment if not provided
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

This approach:

1. Makes `name` parameter explicitly optional with `NULL` default
2. Uses `deparse(substitute(dataset))` only when name isn't provided
3. Captures the variable name as it appears in the caller's code

## Alternative (More Robust)

For a more robust solution that handles complex expressions:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Get the name from caller if not provided
  if (is.null(name)) {
    call <- sys.call()
    mc <- match.call()
    dataset_expr <- mc$dataset
    name <- deparse(dataset_expr)
  }
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

This uses `match.call()` to get the actual expression used for the dataset parameter, which works even with more complex expressions.

I need to evaluate whether the submission correctly addresses the issue based on the given criterion.

The criterion states that the core problem is using `NS(id)` inside the module server function, which creates a new namespace function that doesn't maintain the proper hierarchical relationship with parent modules. The proper fix is to use `session$ns` instead.

Looking at the submission:

1. The submission correctly identifies that there is a namespacing issue in the nested modules.
2. The submission correctly changes `ns <- NS(id)` to `ns <- session$ns` in the innerServer function, which is the exact fix mentioned in the criterion.
3. The submission also correctly fixes the outerServer function by properly namespacing the inner module IDs (`ns("inner1")` etc.).

The submission precisely addresses the main issue identified in the criterion - replacing `NS(id)` with `session$ns` - which ensures that dynamically generated UI elements have fully-qualified namespaces that match their corresponding server outputs.

GRADE: C

samples.input:
I have an R package that depends on a package called, lets say, spatialstuff (This is how it is defined in its DESCRIPTIONS). However it is found in an org and the repo name is different, eg org/spatial-Stuff (i have no control over this name!).

My package in its `DESCRIPTION` file has the following lines

```
Imports:
 spatialstuff
Remotes:
 org/spatial-Stuff
```

However the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow that is run upon pushes (created from `usethis::use_pkgdown_github_pages()`) errors with the following message.

Can someone explain if this is user error or some other error? Thanks

```
! error in pak subprocess
Caused by error:
! Could not solve package dependencies:
deps::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
* local::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* any::sessioninfo: dependency conflict
* any::pkgdown: dependency conflict
```
samples.target: The user needs to specify the package name explicitly in the Remotes `DESCRIPTION` field using a `<package>=` prefix, e.g. `spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff`.

messages.content:

Can someone explain if this is user error or some other error? Thanks

```
! error in pak subprocess
Caused by error:
! Could not solve package dependencies:
deps::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
* local::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* any::sessioninfo: dependency conflict
* any::pkgdown: dependency conflict
```

content.text:
# Error in pkgdown GitHub Action Workflow

The error message suggests there's an issue with resolving the `spatialstuff` dependency during the pkgdown workflow. This appears to be related to how the `Remotes` field is being interpreted by the package manager (pak) in the GitHub Actions environment.

## Likely Causes

1. **Case sensitivity mismatch**: The package name in `Imports` must exactly match what's declared in the remote package's own DESCRIPTION file.

2. **Format of Remotes entry**: The GitHub repository reference may need to be more specific.

## Recommended Solutions

Try one of these approaches:

### Option 1: Use GitHub URL format in Remotes

```
Remotes:
  github::org/spatial-Stuff@main
```

The `github::` prefix explicitly tells R this is a GitHub repo, and `@main` specifies the branch.

### Option 2: Use full URL notation

```
Remotes:
  https://github.com/org/spatial-Stuff
```

### Option 3: Make sure the package name matches the declared name

If the package in `org/spatial-Stuff` declares itself as something other than `spatialstuff` in its DESCRIPTION file, you need to use that exact name in your `Imports`.

Check that the case matches exactly - R package names are case-sensitive.

### Option 4: Explicitly install the dependency in your GitHub workflow

You can modify your GitHub workflow YAML to include a step that explicitly installs the dependency before running pkgdown:

```yaml
- name: Install dependencies
  run: |
    remotes::install_github("org/spatial-Stuff")
  shell: Rscript {0}
```

## Debugging

If these solutions don't work, check:

1. The exact package name declared in the DESCRIPTION file of the `org/spatial-Stuff` repository
2. If the repository is private and requires authentication
3. If there are other dependencies that could be causing conflicts

This is likely a configuration issue rather than a bug in pkgdown or GitHub Actions.

content.text:
# Understanding Your GitHub Packages Error

The error you're encountering is related to how package references are resolved during the pkgdown build process. This is a common issue when using GitHub-hosted packages with different package and repository names.

## The Issue

The problem is that while you've correctly specified both:
- The package name (`spatialstuff`) in your Imports
- The GitHub repository path (`org/spatial-Stuff`) in your Remotes

The pkgdown GitHub Actions workflow is having trouble connecting these two pieces of information.

## Solution Options

### Option 1: Use the GitHub Dependency Syntax in Remotes

Try changing your Remotes line to explicitly connect the package name with the repo:

```
Remotes:
  org/spatial-Stuff@*release
```

or more explicitly:

```
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff
```

### Option 2: Modify the pkgdown workflow

You may need to add an extra step in your GitHub workflow file (.github/workflows/pkgdown.yaml) to install the dependency manually before building the documentation:

```yaml
- name: Install dependencies
  run: |
    remotes::install_github("org/spatial-Stuff")
  shell: Rscript {0}
```

### Option 3: Check the package structure

Ensure that the DESCRIPTION file in the `org/spatial-Stuff` repository correctly specifies its package name as `spatialstuff`. If there's a mismatch there, it would cause this kind of error.

## Related Considerations

- Package names in R should only contain letters, numbers, and dots (not hyphens), which might explain why the GitHub repo name differs from the R package name
- Make sure you're using the latest version of pkgdown and its GitHub Actions workflow

This appears to be a configuration issue rather than a user error - you're attempting to do things the right way, but the tools need a bit more explicit guidance to connect the repository to the package name.

content.text:
# Understanding the R Package Dependency Error

This error appears to be related to how you're specifying your remote dependency. The issue is that there's a mismatch between how `pak` (the package installer used by GitHub Actions) is interpreting your dependency information.

## The Problem

When you have:
```
Imports:
  spatialstuff
Remotes:
  org/spatial-Stuff
```

The package system is looking for a package named `spatialstuff` (lowercase, no hyphens), but the remote repository is named `spatial-Stuff` (with hyphen, mixed case).

## Solution

You need to explicitly tell the package system that the package name `spatialstuff` corresponds to the GitHub repository `org/spatial-Stuff`. The correct format is:

```
Imports:
  spatialstuff
Remotes:
  org/spatial-Stuff@*release
```

Or, for more clarity, you can use the explicit GitHub remote specification:

```
Remotes:
  github::org/spatial-Stuff
```

If the package name inside the repository differs from the repository name, you should be even more explicit:

```
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=github::org/spatial-Stuff
```

This tells the package system that the package named `spatialstuff` should be installed from the GitHub repository `org/spatial-Stuff`.

## Additional Troubleshooting

If that doesn't work, you might need to check:

1. That the package in the repository actually declares itself as `spatialstuff` in its DESCRIPTION file
2. That the repository is public or your GitHub Action has appropriate access
3. That the package is in the root of the repository, not in a subdirectory

The explicit mapping approach should solve the issue by making the connection between package name and repository location clear to the package management system.
